titlestmt.titleproper: Dover, N.H. First Parish Church records, 1614-1862.
titlestmt.author: Susan Stanley, Zachary Bodnar, Jules Thomson

seriesstmt.p: Portions of this collection are part of New England's Hidden Histories. Digital historical representations of these portions of the collection can be viewed online.

conventiondeclaration.citation: Describing Archives: A Content Standard, Second Edition (DACS)

maintenanceevent.eventdescription: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Monday January 13, 2020 at 16:57

did.unittitle: Dover, N.H. First Parish Church records, 1614-1862.
did.abstract: Gathered in 1633, the First Parish Church in Dover is the oldest church in New Hampshire. Rev. Hanserd Knollys organized the First Parish Church as a religious organization in 1638. The church joined the United Church of Christ in 1961 and the name changed to First Parish Congregational Church in 1996. Records include births, marriages, deaths, dismissals, disciplinary cases, meeting minutes, financial records, and pew plans; letters by Rev. Jeremy Belknap, Rev. Hubbard Winslow, and the church's clerk Asa A. Tufts, and between congregations.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is unrestricted and open to the public.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Items in this collection are subject to U.S. Copyright Law. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine the copyright status of collection items and to secure any permissions necessary for their reproduction and publication. Requests for permission to publish material must be discussed with the archivist or librarian.

Digital Reproductions are protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use the Digital Reproductions in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. In addition, no permission is required from the Congregational Library & Archives for educational uses. For other uses, you need to obtain permission from the Congregational Library & Archives. For additional information regarding copyright, please consult the Congregational Library & Archives' Digital Collections Copyright & Use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], in the Dover, N.H. First Parish Church records, 1614-1862, RG1319. The Congregational Library & Archives, Boston, MA.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials were received at two different dates. Microform materials (RG1319) were received at an unknown date. The remaining materials (originally RG5360) were loaned to the Congregational Library & Archives from the First Parish Congregational Church (Dover, N.H.); Accession 2017-17.

originalsloc.head: Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: The physical materials in this collection are held by the First Parish Church in Dover, New Hampshire. The Congregational Library & Archives maintains digital and microfilm surrogates for much of the colection.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Additional accruals are expected for this collection in the form of full-text transcription. There is no anticipated date for this accrual.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Microfilm copies were created by the Genealogical Society, Salt Lake City, Utah, in 1967.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Susan Stanley, March 2018, using DACS Second Edition. Additional description by Zachary Bodnar, February 2019. Item level descriptions by Jules Thomson, January 2020.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Gathered in 1633, the First Parish Church in Dover is the oldest church in New Hampshire. The first permanent settlement in New Hampshire, the lands that would eventually become Dover were initially settled by a pair of fishmongers from London. In 1633, the land was bought by a group of English Puritans. Over the next 150 years, with the arrival of mills and other infrastructure, the small settlement grew in population, size and prosperity.

The settlement's first church services were held on the last Sunday of October 1633 by Rev. Leverich at Dover Point; a year later the first meeting house was built on the same location. Little is known about the first meeting house except that it was made of mud and logs with a thatched roof and that it served the community's purposes until 1658 when a new meeting house was erected on Dover Neck. The third meeting house was located on Pine Hill from 1710-1759. In 1758 the fourth meeting house, built out of wood, was constructed in Tuttle Square. Construction on the fifth, and final, meeting house, a new brick church building, was concluded with its dedication on December 31, 1829.

Rev. William Leverich was the first minister to hold church services in Dover in 1633 and is considered the founder of Mission and Action in Dover. Rev. Hanserd Knollys organized the First Parish Church as a religious organization in 1638. Rev. Jeremy Belknap, who wrote the three volume "History of New Hampshire" and founded the Massachusetts Historical Society in 1791, was the minister at the First Parish from 1769-1786. Rev. David Root was well-known for his opposition to slavery and his anti-slavery sermons, as was his successor Rev. Jeremiah S. Young, who on October 28, 1841 passed a resolution against slavery.

The First Parish Church joined the United Church of Christ in 1961 and in 1996 the name changed to First Parish Congregational Church in 1996. It is a member of the New Hampshire Conference, UCC and of the Carroll-Strafford Association. The First Parish Congregational Church continues to serve the community of Dover, New Hampshire, today.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Dover, N.H. First Parish Church records consist of administrative church records and correspondence from 1614-1862. The scope includes records of births, marriages, deaths, meeting minutes, financial records, and pew plans; letters by appointed clergymen, including Jeremy Belknap, Hubbard Winslow, and Asa A. Tufts, between congregations, and from parishioners wishing to leave the congregation. Microfilm materials duplicate some of the physical material but additional correspondence not present in the physical material are present on the microfilm.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is divided into three series. Records in each series have been arranged chronologically, by start date, and by topic.

phystech.head: Technical Requirements
phystech.p: A microfilm reader is required in order to access microform materials. One microfilm reader is available to the public upon request.

To access digital user's copies via online-interface, a java-enabled web browser is required. Internet Explorer 8.x and later, Firefox 5.x and later, Opera 12 and later, Safari 5.x and later, or any version of Google Chrome are recommended.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: Bryant, Donald R. History of the First Parish Church Founded 1633. Dover: First Parish Church, 2002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence contains letters by appointed clergymen, including Jeremy Belknap, Hubbard Winslow, David Root, Asa A. Tufts, Homer Barrows, and Jeremiah Young. There are correspondences between congregations and letters written on paper with the anti-slavery letterhead from parishioners wishing to leave the congregation.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: This document was digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This single-page document consists of a "letter of public assurance" addressed "to all public officers and others in this jurisdiction whom this may concern". The content relates to the case of Separatist minister "Mr. Hansard Knollys" (Rev. Hanserd Knollys, 1599â€“1691) who was subject to prosecution on charges brought against him by the high commission court in England. In the letter, the unsigned authors grant legal assurance of safe passage for Rev. Knollys during his trial.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These six items of correspondence were all authored by the Rev. Jeremy Belknap, a Congregational minister better known for his contributions to the corpus of American historical works. After twenty years as minister to the Parish Church in Dover, Rev. Belknap resigned due to the church's failure to resolve his salary complaints. The letters ennumerated below correspond to this dispute, which reached a breaking point in the spring and summer of 1786 and resulted in Rev. Belknap's dissolution of his ministry.

defitem.label: 1786 April 30
defitem.item: from Rev. Belknap to the First Parish in Dover: letter regarding Rev. Belknap's effort to lobby for an increase in salary due to the depreciation of paper currency

defitem.label: 1786 June 12
defitem.item: from Rev. Belknap to the First Parish in Dover: letter declining the church committee's invitation to converse about the current "difficulties"

defitem.label: 1786 June 15
defitem.item: from Rev. Belknap to the First Parish in Dover: letter confirming Rev. Belknap's decision to resign from his former duties

defitem.label: 1786 June 16
defitem.item: from Rev. Belknap to the First Parish in Dover: letter with a further reiteration of Rev. Belknap's intentions

defitem.label: 1786 June 16
defitem.item: from Rev. Belknap to the First Parish in Dover: letter with request for an official dismissal or alternatively the convening of an Ecclesiastical Council to decide the matter

defitem.label: 1786 July 27
defitem.item: from Rev. Belknap to the First Parish in Dover: typewritten copy of an original letter elaborating on the reasons for Rev. Belknap's resignation, including objection to the practice of a general parish tax as a means to pay his salary

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These official church records deal mainly with ministerial business, including invitations to clergy to preach and their responses. There is also a parishioner recommendation letter and a copy of meeting minutes. Items are ennumerated below.

defitem.label: 1828 September 13
defitem.item: by Asa Tufts [secretary]: meeting minutes

defitem.label: 1828 November 23
defitem.item: from Hubbard Windlay to the Church and Society of the First Congregational Parish of Dover: letter declining invitation to preach regularly

defitem.label: 1831 November 30
defitem.item: from J. H. Keeler to Asa Tufts: letter excusing himself from an ecclesiastical council

defitem.label: 1831 December 7
defitem.item: from "L" to [unknown]: letter requesting references for two potential ministers

defitem.label: 1832 May 28
defitem.item: from A. D. Eddy to William Woodman: letter with description of recent travels

defitem.label: 1832 October 23
defitem.item: from Warren Fay to the First Church in Dover: letter declining ministerial call

defitem.label: 1838 August 6
defitem.item: from the Congregational Church in Great Falls to the First Church in Dover: letter of recommendation for parishioner Oliver Carter

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These records relate to the ministry of Rev. H. Winslow, specifically the end of his ministry, his health concerns, and the search for a replacement minister.

defitem.label: 1831 June 11
defitem.item: from Rev. H. Winslow to "the wardens of the First Parish in Dover": letter describing his health concerns and need for a new pastor

defitem.label: 1831 June 11
defitem.item: from Rev. H. Winslow to "the wardens of the First Parish in Dover": copy of above letter with reply from church wardens

defitem.label: 1831 November 13
defitem.item: from Rev. H. Winslow to Dr. Asa A. Tufts: letter describing his health concerns

defitem.label: 1831 November 30
defitem.item: by Israel W. Putnam [moderator]: results of an ecclesiastical council dismissing Rev. Winslow

defitem.label: 1831 December 11
defitem.item: from H. Winslow to Dr. Asa A. Tufts: letter suggesting replacement ministers

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These records relate to the church's attempt to instate Rev. J. Turnbull Backus as minister, and Backus's refusals of the call. One letter includes arrangements for temporary preaching.

defitem.label: 1831 August 19
defitem.item: from Allen Gannett to William Woodman: recommendation of J. T. Backus as replacement minister

defitem.label: 1832 February 13
defitem.item: from J. Turnbull Backus to William Woodman: letter declining the ministerial call

defitem.label: 1831 October 31
defitem.item: from J. Turnbull Backus to William Woodman: letter reiterating his poor health and declining the ministerial call

defitem.label: 1831 August 24
defitem.item: from J. Turnbull Backus to William Woodman: letter with arrangements for preaching

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These records, mainly correspondence, relate to the ministry of Rev. David Root, specifically to his illness and resignation. They include letters from Rev. Root to the church committee and replies.

defitem.label: undated
defitem.item: from Rev. David Root to the First Parish in Dover: copy of letter declining preaching due to ill health

defitem.label: 1833 January 21
defitem.item: from Rev. David Root to the committee of the First Church and Parish in Dover: letter regarding his ministry

defitem.label: 1834 April 24
defitem.item: from Charles Ricker to Rev. David Root: letter regarding his dismission

defitem.label: 1835 March 25
defitem.item: from J. H. Miller to the First Church in Dover: invitation to an ecclesiastical council for the merging of the Pleasant Street Church in Portsmouth, N.H. and the North Church

defitem.label: 1835 May 28
defitem.item: from Rev. David Root to the First Parish of Dover: copy of resignation letter

defitem.label: 1837 June 10
defitem.item: from Rev. David Root to the First Congregational Church of Dover: letter calling for an ecclesiastical council regarding his resignation

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These records relate to the disciplinary case of parishioner Daniel Norris, resulting from a financial dispute with other parishioners. Documents include legal testimonials by witnesses and plaintifs in the case, summons to the hearing, and finally Norris's confession to the church. Items are ennumerated below.

defitem.label: 1834 February 10
defitem.item: by T. E. Sawyer: copy of receipt by Richard McDuffee to Thomas Roberts, with elaboration of legal dispute

defitem.label: 1835 March 17
defitem.item: from John W. Hayes to Daniel Norris [on behalf of the church]: letter with summons to a disciplinary hearing

defitem.label: 1835 March 23
defitem.item: by Thomas Roberts : legal testimony

defitem.label: 1835 March 26
defitem.item: by John W. Hayes: report on disciplinary case of Daniel Norris

defitem.label: 1835 January 19
defitem.item: by Thomas Pickering, David Legro, and Richard McDuffee: legal testimony

defitem.label: 1839 February 5
defitem.item: from Daniel Norris to the congregation of the First Church in Dover: confession and request for forgiveness

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These records comprise letters to and from the church in Dover, discussing pulpit supply and preaching, disciplinary cases of parishioners, and one request for dismissal. Items are ennumerated below.

defitem.label: 1839 August 28
defitem.item: from E. J. Lane to Rev. Mr. Young: letter with request for pulpit supply

defitem.label: 1839 September 4
defitem.item: from William J. Breed to E. J. Lane: letter making arrangements for preaching

defitem.label: 1839 October 10
defitem.item: from Rev. J. S. Young to the committee of the First Church in Dover: letter declining offer to continue preaching

defitem.label: 1842 July 6
defitem.item: from Rev. J. S. Young to Charles Ricker: letter with summons to a disciplinary hearing

defitem.label: 1842 July 8
defitem.item: from E. J. Lane to Mr. Palfrey Downing: letter with summons to a disciplinary meeting

defitem.label: 1842 July 10
defitem.item: from Elizabeth L. Fols to the Congregational Church in Dover: letter asking for dismissal

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These records relate to the departure of several parishioners from the church in Dover, and the church's subsequent dismissal of the members. In a document submitted to the church, the absenting members describe their opposition to the church's refusal to condemn slavery.

defitem.label: 1842 October 9
defitem.item: from Abraham Folsom to the First Congregational Church in Dover: letter regarding the abolition of slavery

defitem.label: 1842 October 9
defitem.item: by the First Church in Dover: letter dismissing Abraham Folsom and other members

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These records consist of official church correspondence, including parishioner transfer letters, ministers' letters, invitations to ecclesiastical councils, and summons to disciplinary meetings. Items are ennumerated below.

defitem.label: 1845 June 14
defitem.item: from Homer Barrow to the First Congregational Church and Society in Dover: letter with acceptance of ministerial call

defitem.label: 1845 June 23
defitem.item: from the First Congregational Church of Christ in Dover to the Congregational Church of Christ in Rochester: invitation to ecclesiastical council for the ordination of Rev. Homer Barrow

defitem.label: 1848 September 4
defitem.item: from the First Church in Dover to the First Presbyterian Church in Newburyport: parishioner transfer of Hannah Coffin

defitem.label: undated
defitem.item: from the First Church in Dover to the Baptist Church in Dover: parishioner transfer of "Miss A. B."

defitem.label: undated
defitem.item: from the First Church in Dover to Daniel Gale: letter with summons to a disciplinary hearing

defitem.label: undated
defitem.item: from the First Church in Dover to Samuel Prescott: letter with summons to a disciplinary hearing

defitem.label: 1849 March 1
defitem.item: from Hayden K. Higby to E. J. Lane: letter requesting letter of transfer to the Old South Church in Boston

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These records comprise four invitations to ecclesiastical councils, from other churches to the church in Dover. The invitations are for ordinations and dismissions of ministers.

defitem.label: 1853 December 22
defitem.item: from the Congregational Church in Great Falls to the Congregational Church in Dover: invitation to ecclesiastical council for dismission of Rev. McCollom

defitem.label: 1853 December 12
defitem.item: from the Congregational Church in Epping to the Congregational Church in Dover: invitation to ecclesiastical council for the ordination of Rev. Lyman White

defitem.label: 1855 October 31
defitem.item: from the Congregational Church in Hampton to the Congregational Church in Dover: invitation to ecclesiastical council for the ordination of Rev. John Colby

defitem.label: 1855 October 22
defitem.item: from the North Church and Parish in Portsmouth, N.H. to the Congregational Church in Dover: invitation to ecclesiastical council for the ordination of Rev. Lyman Whiting

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Church Records include records of births, marriages, deaths, meeting minutes and financial outlines of the pews. There are documents regarding the instalment of Rev. Benjamin F. Parsons, lists of congregation members, documents regarding the situation of A. Farnsworth, and tax documents.

did.unittitle: Church record of marriages, baptisms and deaths

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Church Record of Marriages, Baptisms, and Deaths is a volume containing records of Marriages: May 1767 - Jan. 1829; and Baptisms and deaths: Oct. 1717 - Dec. 1786. It is signed by Jeremy Belknap.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This record book consists of committee reports, meeting minutes, correspondence drafts and copies, as well as financial records.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Between pages 122-123, three loose documents were found in and placed in their own folder: Tax Documents 1781-1784.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Curch record book vol. 1 contains Jeremy Belknap's historical notes on the town and church of Dover until October 1789. The volume also contains records of marriages and baptisms, lists of members admitted to the church, a list of the childrne of Rev. Jonathan Cushing, and notes written by other clergymen.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Church record book vol. 2 contains names of church members, records of deaths and baptisms, notices of ministers, and prints of Rev. Hubbard Winslow, Rev. David Root, and Hanserd Knollys There are printed church manual clippings as well as a photograph of Dea. Lane. The title leaf is signed by Asa A. Tufts in 1831.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These three loose documents were found in the church record book dating to 1762-1862, between pages 122-123, and placed in their own folder.

defitem.label: 1781 April 10
defitem.item: by Rev. Jeremy Belknap: notice of receipt for parish taxes levied

defitem.label: 1784 May 1
defitem.item: by Stephen Evans to the parish wardens: request for payment of one pound, nine shilling and sixpence from the parish collection of 1782

defitem.label: undated
defitem.item: list of payments received from various subscribers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These records comprise official church correspondence and include invitations to ecclesiastical councils, ordinations, articles of faith and church covenant documents.

defitem.label: undated
defitem.item: [used by] Rev. Clary: articles of faith

defitem.label: 1828 August 6

defitem.label: 1831 November 16

defitem.label: 1832 June 6

defitem.label: 1833 February 6

defitem.label: 1833 January 25

defitem.label: 1834 July 15
defitem.item: articles of faith and covenant

defitem.label: 1835 September 17
defitem.item: from the Congregational Church in Rochester to the Church in Dover: invitation to ecclesiastical council to dismiss pastor

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These four documents relate to a disciplinary case against parishioner Asa Farnsworth, who was allegedly seen going into the bedroom of the widow Mrs. Benn without anyone besides the two of them present.

defitem.label: 1840 December 5
defitem.item: by Francis Cogswell and others: committee report on Asa Farnsworth's behavior toward the widow Mrs. Benn

defitem.label: 1841 April 9
defitem.item: from Asa Farnsworth to the Congregational Church of Dover: letter relating to his own disciplinary case

defitem.label: 1841 June 28
defitem.item: from Asa Farnsworth to the Congregational Church of Dover: letter relating to his own disciplinary case

defitem.label: undated
defitem.item: draft of ruling in Asa Farnsworth's disciplinary case

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These records consist of official church and parish documents, including several meeting minutes and invitations, and also several financial reports. Items are ennumerated below.

defitem.label: 1845 May 11
defitem.item: by E. J. Lane [clerk]: church and parish meeting minutes

defitem.label: 1849 December 2
defitem.item: by E. J. Lane [clerk]: church meeting minutes

defitem.label: 1849 December 5
defitem.item: by B. R. Allen [moderator]: ecclesiastical council meeting minutes

defitem.label: 1852 July 6
defitem.item: by Adam Jobey [moderator]: ecclesiastical council meeting minutes

defitem.label: 1852 May 27
defitem.item: meeting notice

defitem.label: 1853 December 16
defitem.item: from the Mather Church and Society to the First Church in Dover: invitation to ecclesiastical council for ordination

defitem.label: 1854 March 31
defitem.item: list of subscribers for the American Sunday School Union

defitem.label: 1855 January 1
defitem.item: reports of the church treasury committee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These documents relate to the selection and ordination of Rev. Benjamin Parsons, including correspondence to and from the First Parish Church in Dover. Items are ennumerated below.

defitem.label: 1852 December 28
defitem.item: from Benjamin Parsons to the Congregational Church and parish in Dover: letter with acceptance of ministerial call

defitem.label: 1852 December 29
defitem.item: from Benjamin Parsons to the Congregational Church and parish in Dover: addendum to acceptance of call with salary request

defitem.label: 1852 December 31
defitem.item: from the Congregational Church in Dover to S. L. Pomroy: invitation letter to the installation of Rev. Parsons

defitem.label: 1853 January 12
defitem.item: by B. N. Allen [moderator]: results of ecclesiastical council for the settlement of Rev. Parsons

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The microfilms contain death, marriage, and baptismal records, calendar notes, and meeting minutes. Also containing letters from Jeremy Belknap and other documents, these microfilms contain much of the material from Series 1 and 2.
